So… OpFlash Dragon Rising…

OpFlash Dragon Rising.

The experience surrounding the acquisition and installation of the game was almost more interesting than the game, this time.  When all the planets align, buying a game off Steam and playing it can indeed be as smooth an experience as a console.

In this case, the game and all its dependencies installed flawlessly, then the game ran pretty much flawlessly at my display's native 1080p resolution WITHOUT there being any annoying gfx quality settings to worry about.  And finally, when you plug in an Xbox 360 controller, it is not only 100% supported, but even the on-screen key guides change to controller buttons.  (The best 360 controller support on PC in my thus far limited experience.)

The game itself.  Eh…  Yeah.  I *want* to like it.  I like the *idea* of a military shooter that's somewhere between Battlefield and ArmA.  But in practice, after a couple of missions, I cannot say I feel remotely immersed.  I'm still willing to give it another shot, though.  And then I'll report back again.

NightSky is today's daily deal, which I actually don't know anything about, except that it's by the guy who made Knytt, which I *love*. (Free, here: http://nifflas.ni2.se/content/Knytt/Knytt%20102.zip)

Sounds promising: "In NightSky the player controls a glowing sphere which can accelerate and decelerate, and sometimes has the ability to invert gravity. The goal is to guide the sphere through 10 different worlds, each divided into 13 three-screen sections, each section containing a challenge or a puzzle."
"Atmospheric, charming and ethereal" is hitting all the right buttons, because Knytt had the same qualities in spades. Knytt might not look like much, it nails atmosphere better than a lot of AAAs.

"As is the way with these things, it's not enough for NightSky to simply be atmospheric, charming and ethereal; it has to bare its teeth and turn into a right sod, just at the point when you're telling everyone how much you love it.

But if you can break through the periodic pain barrier that comes with such exacting physics-based challenges, you'll be able to bask in the warm glow of manly gaming satisfaction. And with around six hours' worth of it to roll through, it'll put hairs on your chest."
How much is it, btw?

Oh, whoops, I forgot to review this in time, didn't I?

It's enjoyable, and the atmosphere's there (think Limbo) but due to the nature of the game, it feels more tacked on than organic. What made Knytt wonderful was how seamless and natural the (entirely bizarre) world felt, despite being a low-fi basic 2D platformer. You felt like you'd visited and explored an alien world by the end of it. There's not much of that same feeling here, I guess I was expecting something different.
